subscriptionSummary.default: A pilot who started as a teenage apprentice has flown his last Qantas service after five decades, declaring the airline’s early management style would have destroyed the company.

headline.default: After 55 years, a Qantas pilot’s frank verdict

standfirst.default: A pilot who started as a teenage apprentice has flown his last Qantas service after five decades, declaring the airline’s early management style would have destroyed the company.

a78dd9ba0098341f667cf7193c747f80.captionOverride: Captain William Byrnes piloted his final flight for Qantas (with First Officer Matthew Loewy) on January 13, 2026, after 55 years with the airline. Picture: Qantas

intro.default: A Qantas pilot who served the airline for more than half of its 105 years, says the company would not have survived if it was run like it was when he first joined, acknowledging the financial chops of recent chief executives.

482c7c5b4a14e803f379afd2a7c6935b.seoTitle: Captain William Byrnes completes final Qantas flight after 55 years

body.default:
William Byrnes captained his final flight on Tuesday with his wife, children and grandkids on board the Adelaide to Sydney service to mark the end of his remarkable 55 year career.

Having started with Qantas as a 16-year-old apprentice engineer in 1971, Captain Byrnes has seen enormous change at the airline, which was then headed by Sir Bert Ritchie. Over the decades, he served under multiple chairs and chief executives including Keith Hamilton, John Menadue, James Strong and Alan Joyce — but declined to nominate a favourite.

“CEOs were a lot different in the early days and naturally, have had to change their style because the company has changed over the years,” said Captain Byrnes, 71. “If the company was run now like it was in the early days when I started, we wouldn’t be here having this talk.”

He did confess to being “gobsmacked” to be greeted by current chief executive Vanessa Hudson when he disembarked from his last flight in Sydney.

Ms Hudson had “taken the time to come down and congratulate” Captain Byrnes which he declared was “a bit above and beyond I think”.

Throughout his long tenure, there was no shortage of drama on the ground at Qantas, from the chaotic 1989 pilots dispute and Mr Joyce’s controversial 2011 lockout of staff to the bleak Covid years. Yet Captain Byrnes said he never seriously considered leaving the airline for another carrier.

“It’s the old story of the grass is always greener, but we were only talking the other day about chaps my colleagues know who have ventured out to other airlines and now they’re trying to get back into Qantas,” he said. “It becomes a bit difficult once you’ve left Qantas and gone elsewhere.”

In the air, Captain Byrnes also experienced his fair share of excitement from “engine shutdowns and tyres blowing up on takeoff, to people having heart attacks just after takeoff”.

He said the most challenging part of the job was “weather” which he believed was probably getting worse, and nominated Beijing as his least favourite port to fly into due to the “erratic air traffic control”.

“I was still flight engineering at the time when we flew into Beijing when it first opened to Australian tourism,” he recalled.

“That was very interesting, the air traffic control, you had to keep your wits about you. But they’re as good as any now, they’ve come a long way very rapidly.”

On the other hand New York remained his favourite destination, with fond memories of operating Boeing 747s to the city.

“We had many great times in New York, always alive, always fantastic,” Captain Byrnes said.

Unlike some of his former colleagues, Captain Byrnes had no plans to “downsize” his flying to private aircraft, nor would he seek to renew his licence when it expired next month.

And despite spending most of his working life travelling to all corners of the globe, Captain Byrnes said he was looking forward to doing a lot more flying — as a passenger.

“It’s a different kind of travel when you’re on holidays. You’re not constrained to crew hotels, or commercial pressures of having to be in a place at a certain time,” he said.

Although his children had chosen not to follow him into aviation, Captain Byrnes was convinced it remained a tremendous career “for the right person”.

“It becomes a passion, and once you start flying you either know that you have it or you don’t. So you’re sort of a slave to the industry. You become enmeshed with the joy of flying, and you just can’t say no.”

extendedHeadline.default: ‘A slave to the industry’: Qantas pilot reflects on 55-year career

subscriptionSummary.default: The Adelaide Writers’ Week director has stepped down in the wake of pro-Palestine activist Randa Abdel-Fattah’s controversial axing and the subsequent departure of 180 writers, saying she ‘cannot be party to silencing writers’.

headline.default: Writers Week axed – could Adelaide Festival be next?

standfirst.default: The event has been cancelled and the entire board has been replaced following a boycott by 180 authors over censorship claims that could reshape Australia’s literary landscape.

63471be58f36966c9e6d5fc22fbb8491.captionOverride: Jihadist chic? Sorry Randa, it’s out, darling

891418da59403b0282fed027dc02f4bb.captionOverride: Woke warfare: Writers’ festivals in the age of Gaza and gender

b77ed412a54f3451c62deb8da917c16f.captionOverride: Chair, board members quit Adelaide Festival amid boycott ‘hypocrisy’

9767348608a65844f972bf508585c925.captionOverride: Just another boring writers’ festival where everyone agrees with each other

f42d0680e179a241067d6f46a2a22d6c.captionOverride: Louise Adler, left, and Randa Abdel-Fattah.

335cdb7245bd7906ec284a046ddacf28.captionOverride: Adelaide Writers Week director Louise Adler has quit. Picture: Kristoffer Paulsen

aa838e4dcef16f9d5629ffdccbed13d2.altText: Author Randa Abdel-Fattah at her home in Sydney.
aa838e4dcef16f9d5629ffdccbed13d2.captionOverride: Author Randa Abdel-Fattah at her home in Sydney. Picture: News Corp Australia

intro.default: The future of the Adelaide Festival is under threat after the un­precedented cancellation of its Writers Week, the explosive resignation of director Louise Adler, and the dissolution – followed by an emergency reappointment – of the festival’s board.

be106ec225ea4a527c691554293ce83c.seoTitle: Adelaide Writers Week axed after 180 authors boycott festival

socialHeadline.default: Adelaide Writers Week axed after 180 authors boycott festival

body.default:
In what was the most seismic day in the Australian cultural sector in recent memory, an apology by the outgoing festival board to controversial disinvited Palestinian-Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah was publicly rejected, with the writer claiming it was “disingenuous”.

Following the news that Ms Adler had resigned and Writers Week would be cancelled, and its remaining three-person board dissolved, South Australian Arts Minister Andrea Michaels on Tuesday evening named a new board, to be chaired by the experienced Judy Potter, who led the board between 2016 and 2023.

Respected Adelaide arts leader and former Adelaide Festival executive director and administrator Rob Brookman also was named, alongside media figure Jane Doyle and financial services identity John Irving. They will operate alongside Mary Couros, the incumbent Adelaide City Council-nominated member who will see out her term, which expires in February this year.

Ms Michaels said the festival was a “treasured institution”.

“It belongs to the people of South Australia and transcends any individual. It is vital we safeguard the festival for the future, which is why today I have appointed a board of experienced and trusted South Australians to ensure the 2026 Adelaide Festival can proceed under new leadership,” she said. “Judy Potter successfully stewarded the Adelaide Festival for more than eight years. She is a forthright, skilful leader and I am grateful she has returned to lead this task.”

Focus shifted to the Adelaide Festival, the country’s largest and most prestigious arts jamboree, and whether it too was vulnerable to cancellation. American Peter Sellars, a former Adelaide Festival artistic director, was one of 17 former AF chiefs and administrators to sign an open letter condemning the board’s decision to cancel Dr Abdel-Fattah over historic comments on Israel and demanding she be reinstated. Sellars is due to make his long-awaited-return to Adelaide, to direct Perle Noire: Meditations for Josephine. Sellars, who left his post controversially in Adelaide 24 years ago before a curtain had even been raised, was contacted for comment. As at the time of writing, his work remained in the festival program.

The other big question hanging over the festival is the free opening night concert on February 27 by British rock band Pulp. The band is led by the charismatic Jarvis Cocker, who has publicly supported the Palestinian cause. The band’s Instagram posts have been overrun with comments urging the band to reconsider its appearance in the South Australian capital. Activist group Musicians for Palestine launched a social media campaign on Monday, urging followers to fill the band’s social media comment sections with phrases such as “boycott Adelaide Festival” or “Solidarity with Randa”. Hundreds of messages on Tuesday were visible on the band’s Instagram page. The group’s aim was “to get them to pull out of the festival”, it said. Pulp, as of Tuesday evening, remained in the program, an AF spokesperson said.

Reportedly, a portion of the contemporary music program had been abandoned, with acts having pulled out in protest at the board’s treatment of Dr Abdel-Fattah. However, an AF spokesperson said that the club Tryp program remained part of the ­festival line-up.

A statement on Tuesday announced Adelaide Writers Week had been cancelled, and the presiding board dissolved, with the AF in a statement apologising to Dr Abdel-Fattah “for how the decision was represented”.

The news came hours after Ms Adler resigned with a both-barrels op-ed in The Guardian claiming Adelaide risked becoming “Moscow on the Torrens”, following the withdrawal of 180 writers over the cancellation of Dr Abdel-Fattah.

“On 8 January, 2026 the Adelaide Festival Board made a decision to rescind the invitation of Dr Randa Abdel-Fattah to participate in Adelaide Writers Week 2026,” the statement read. “As a board we took this action out of respect for a community experiencing the pain from a devastating event. Instead, this decision has created more division and for that we express our sincere apologies.

“Many authors have since announced they will no longer appear at Adelaide Writers Week 2026 and it is the Adelaide Festival’s position that the event can no longer go ahead as scheduled for this year. This is a deeply regrettable outcome.

“We recognise and deeply regret the distress this decision has caused to our audience, artists and writers, donors, corporate partners, the government and our own staff and people. We also apologise to Dr Randa Abdel-Fattah for how the decision was represented and reiterate this is not about identity or dissent but rather a continuing rapid shift in the ­national discourse around the breadth of freedom of expression in our nation following Australia’s worst terror attack in history.”

Dr Abdel-Fattah, however, publicly refused the apology, saying it was “disingenuous”.

“Because I have too much respect for myself and for my people, for those who have suffered irreparable harm by the board’s conduct, for the brilliant Louise Adler who was forced on principle to resign, I refuse and reject the board’s apology,” she posted on Instagram on Tuesday. “It is disingenuous. It adds insult to injury.”

Dr Abdel-Fattah added: “It is clear that the board’s regret extends to how the message of my cancellation was conveyed, not the decision itself. Once again, the board citing the ‘national discourse’ for an action that specifically targets me, a Palestinian Australian Muslim woman, is explicitly articulating that I cannot be part of the national discourse.”

Earlier, Ms Adler warned the festival was “the canary in the coalmine” and creatives should be aware “they are coming for you”.

Announcing her resignation, Ms Adler said she was standing down in the wake of a decision by the Adelaide Festival to cancel Dr Abdel-Fattah for historic comments about Israel.

“The decision to disinvite (Dr Abdel-Fattah) … weakens freedom of speech and is the harbinger of a less free nation, where lobbying and political pressure determine who gets to speak and who doesn’t,” Ms Adler wrote.

“Writers and writing matters, even when they are presenting ideas that discomfort and challenge us.

“We need writers now more than ever, as our media closes up, as our politicians grow daily more cowed by real power, as Australia grows more unjust and ­unequal.”

Ms Adler claimed the situation was symptomatic of a wider social malaise.

“With alarming insouciance, protests are being outlawed, free speech is being constrained and politicians are rushing through processes to ban phrases and slogans,” she wrote.

“Now religious leaders are to be policed, universities monitored, the public broadcaster scrutinised and the arts starved.

“Are you or have you ever been a critic of Israel? Joe Mc­Carthy would be cheering on the inheritors of his tactics.

“Artists have always been a problem for the state and interest groups but the confrontations have intensified as a consequence of the war on Gaza.”

Adelaide Writers Week, Australia’s largest free arts event, is one of the country’s most prestigious literary festivals.

Orange Prize winner Zadie Smith, Pulitzer Prize winner Percival Everett and former New Zealand prime minister Jacinda Ardern – as well as local literary heroes Helen Garner and Trent Dalton – are among the high-­profile authors who boycotted the event in protest at the decision to disinvite Dr Abdel-Fattah.

The announcement comes a day after influential publisher Morry Schwartz criticised Ms Adler for knowingly harming the event, saying she was aware ­programming the controversial author would be ruinous for the 66-year-old literary festival.

Ms Adler concluded: “A writer is to be cancelled after pressure from pro-Israel lobbyists, bureaucrats and opportunistic politicians. I cannot be party to silencing writers so, with a heavy heart, I am resigning from my role as the director of the AWW.

“AWW is the canary in the coalmine. Friends and colleagues in the arts, beware of the future.

“They are coming for you.”

extendedHeadline.default: Adelaide Writers Week cancelled and new board announced after author row

headline.default: List of key Golden Globe winners

standfirst.default: List of key Golden Globe winners

intro.default: Here are the winners in key categories for the 83rd Golden Globe Awards, which were handed out on Sunday.

body.default:
"One Battle After Another" was the big winner of the night, taking home four awards including best comedy film and best director.

- FILM -

Best film, drama: "Hamnet"

Best film, musical or comedy: "One Battle After Another"

Best male actor, drama: Wagner Moura, "The Secret Agent"

Best female actor, drama: Jessie Buckley, "Hamnet"

Best male actor, musical or comedy: Timothee Chalamet, "Marty Supreme"

Best female actor, musical or comedy: Rose Byrne, "If I Had Legs I'd Kick You"

Best supporting actor: Stellan Skarsgard, "Sentimental Value"

Best supporting actress: Teyana Taylor, "One Battle After Another"

Best director: Paul Thomas Anderson, "One Battle After Another"

Best screenplay: Paul Thomas Anderson, "One Battle After Another"

Best non-English language film: "The Secret Agent" (Brazil)

Best cinematic and box office achievement: "Sinners"

Best animated feature: "KPop Demon Hunters"

- TELEVISION -

Best drama series: "The Pitt"

Best male actor, drama: Noah Wyle, "The Pitt"

Best female actor, drama: Rhea Seehorn, "Pluribus"

Best musical or comedy series: "The Studio"

Best male actor, musical or comedy: Seth Rogen, "The Studio"

Best female actor, musical or comedy: Jean Smart, "Hacks"

Best limited series or TV movie: "Adolescence"

Best male actor, limited series or TV movie : Stephen Graham, "Adolescence"

Best female actor, limited series or TV movie : Michelle Williams, "Dying for Sex"

bur-sst/ksb

extendedHeadline.default: List of key Golden Globe winners

subscriptionSummary.default: From five channels on the couch to bingeing whole seasons on your phone, TV has evolved dramatically in 25 years. Our expert critics and writers have selected the top 25 essential tv shows that had a cultural impact and revolutionised storytelling. Do you agree with our picks? Cast your vote below and let us know your favourites.

headline.default: The 25 best TV shows of the last 25 years

standfirst.default: Our expert critics and writers have chosen the top 25 shows since 2001. Do you agree with our picks? Cast your vote.

f2bef2f11a59da641b47121bbbba2679.altText: Elizabeth Debicki as Princess Diana in The Crown Season 6. Picture: Daniel Escale/Netflix

intro.default: This content is built using the Gutenberg editor. Save the article as draft to begin.

e36a3f37ecb86f1e62ab6566dc27c2bd.seoTitle: Best TV series of all time: Our expert critics name the top 25 most transformative shows

socialHeadline.default: What to watch: Top 25 TV series

body.default:
25 Best TV Shows of the Last 25 Years

October 22, 2025 – 5:00am

Television is almost unrecognisable to what it was in 2001. Gone are the days of waiting weeks or months for the next episode, enduring ad breaks and only five channels to watch in the living room. Today, countless streaming platforms allow us to binge entire seasons on phones during commutes, on laptops in bed or via clips on YouTube. Once dismissed as the “small screen”, television now boasts Hollywood A-list actors, massive budgets and extraordinary global reach. 

These 25 shows were selected by critics and writers Geordie Gray, Graeme Blundell, Richard Ferguson, Troy Bramston, Bianca Farmakis, Joseph Carbone, Steve Jackson and Milanda Rout for their cultural impact and transformative influence. These series redefined storytelling, blew out budgets, challenged traditional hero-villain definitions, dared to kill off protagonists and sparked worldwide conversations.

And if you disagree with our list, you can have your vote below!

25. Slow Horses (2022-present)

Apple TV

Apple’s spy series asks: what if MI5 was staffed by rejects and screw-ups? Gary Oldman’s Jackson Lamb waddles through the wreckage with flatulence and brilliance. A bleakly funny, unexpectedly gripping reminder that the intelligence services are staffed not by Bond, but by people you’d rather not sit next to on the bus.

24. Peaky Blinders (2013-2022)

Netflix

Steven Knight turned Birmingham’s postwar gangsters into a global brand. Cillian Murphy’s Tommy Shelby smokes, schemes, and whispers his way through six series with hypnotic menace. Violent, operatic, and ludicrously stylish. The only TV show to directly cause a global epidemic of terrible men’s haircuts.

23. Black Mirror (2011-present)

Netflix

Art imitates life apparently, considering the techno-hellscape we find ourselves in, and if Charlie Brooker’s dystopian anthology is anything to go by, it’s a wild ride ahead. Scripting brilliance, nail-biting thrills and more celebrity cameos than The Studio could ever dream of aside, who could forget the birth of the “choose your own scenario” screening format the show introduced to us?

22. Chernobyl (2019) 

HBO Max

Across five parts, Craig Mazin and his team took viewers behind the scenes of one of the worst disasters in modern history and the slew of bureaucratic failures that presaged and followed it. Jared Harris and Jessie Buckley are sublime as surrogates for the audience to experience how the aftermath affected the high and low of Russian society. Stellan Skarsgard and Emily Watson are no slouches either.

21. Call My Agent (2015-2020)

SBS On Demand

Surprisingly successful Netflix French comedy Dix Pour Cent, as it’s known at home, about a Parisian talent agency which was such a hit during Covid lockdowns. It also featured a plethora of actors and actors happily playing the worst versions of themselves: Monica Bellucci, Juliette Binoche and Sigourney Weaver.

20. Squid Game (2021-2025)

Netflix

Hwang Dong-hyuk’s deadly dystopian drama became a global phenomenon when more than 111 million people around the world tuned in to watch in just the first 28 days after its Netflix release. The show, based on a children’s game, transcends language and cultural barriers and was such a hit that it even spurned spawned themed meals at McDonald’s. It showed the dual power of global streaming and Korean culture.

19. Normal People (2020)

Stan

A series that sent the girls (and women) rabid during the Covid lockdown. Sally Rooney’s novel about Connell and Marianne’s messy, magnetic love was faithfully adapted, and in the process minted two stars: Paul Mescal’s chain and Daisy Edgar-Jones’s fringe. It captureds the agony, ecstasy, and intensity of first love. Classy, understated, sexy, and sad.

18. Atlanta (2016-2022)

Disney+

Created by and starring rapper and actor Donald Glover, this surreal riff on rap, race and fame gleefully refuses categorisation. One week a sitcom, the next a horror film, the next a Lynchian dreamscape. 

17. Veep (2012-2019)

HBO Max

The American spin-off from Iannucci’s wonderful series The Thick of It, starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus as US vice-president Selina Meyer, is political satire delivered with frightening profanity and usually great speed by an obviously delighted cast. The jokes are always the best part but reality gave it all the material it needed to keep the engine firing.

16. Angels in America (2003)

HBO Max

Mike Nichols and Emma Thompson plus Pulitzer-winning source material equal a guarantee you will bawl your eyes out. In 2003, Nichols and HBO turned Tony Kushner’s stage leviathan into a miniseries, gifting giving us Al Pacino as a despicable Roy Cohn and Meryl Streep as, well, everyone. The AIDS crisis, Reagan-era politics and angels descending on earth might sound like a hard sell but the sweep and passion made it feel like scripture. A rare case of event TV that genuinely merited the phrase, and a show that cemented television as art.

15. The Thick of It (2005-2012)

ABC iView

Armando Iannucci turned Westminster into a farce so accurate it often felt like a leak in this political satire. Peter Capaldi’s Malcolm Tucker elevates profanity into an art form as the prime minister’s director of communications. It is the 21st century’s answer to Yes Minister.

14. Happy Valley (2014-2023)

Stan

Sally Wainwright took the British crime drama and rebuilt it around a middle-aged woman in a hi-vis jacket. Sarah Lancashire gives the performance of her career as Sergeant Catherine Cawood — no gimmicks, no gloss, just grit. Never cosy, never gratuitous. Just writing and acting so strong it doesn’t need to shout.

13. Girls (2012-2017)

HBO Max

Lena Dunham’s Brooklyn quartet drank, shagged, and overshared their way into a millennial manifesto. A cringe-comedy masterclass: Marnie singing Kanye’s Stronger is still one of television’s most unbearable gifts. For every hot take it spawned, the show had already written one for itself. Dunham’s 2025 follow up in London, Too Much, is equally as divisive. 

12. Kath and Kim (2002-2005)

Netflix

Is there any show in the world that encapsulates a nation’s soul quite like Kath and Kim? How Gina Riley and Jane Turner so wonderfully pricked and poked at Australians’ desperation to be “effluent”. Add in Magda Szubanski, and you have the nation’s best ever comedy. Don’t think it represents modern Australia? Look at the last election: the Libs didn’t win because they lost Kath, Kim, Prue, Trude and Sharon in one fell swoop. 

11. The White Lotus (2021-present)

HBO Max

Mike White has given television plenty — from his savage wellness satire Enlightened to that unexpectedly brilliant season of Survivor — but his big hit is The White Lotus. Born of his desire to never set foot on a studio lot again, it strands the extremely well-off in luxury resorts where resentments simmer, privilege curdles, and at least one guest doesn’t make it home. Razor-sharp and gleefully cruel, it skewers the rich while letting us bask in the spectacular scenery. So smart, so funny, so fatal. Ironically tourists now flock to the real-life settings of The White Lotus in Hawaii, Italy and Thailand and there are already bets on where the next series will be set.

10. The Crown (2016-2023)

Netflix

This splendid original drama from Peter Morgan gave us the intimate, immersive story of Queen Elizabeth II and her seven-decade reign, the many personal intrigues, filial affections, clandestine passions and courtly jealousies behind her ascension to the throne. Also memorable for its casting changes, which meant we were treated to both Claire Foy and Olivia Colman as the queen, and Emma Corrin and Australian’s Elizabeth Debicki as Diana. 

9. Mad Men (2007-2015)

Stan

Matthew Weiner’s Madison Avenue epic was ostensibly about advertising but mostly about selling yourself lies you could just about live with. Don Draper smokes, drinks and unravells his way through the 1960s, while the women around him endure pencil skirts and patriarchy – and frequently steal the show. It sent the rest of us on a hopeless quest for mid-century modern furniture.

8. Fleabag (2016-2019)

Amazon Prime

Phoebe Waller-Bridge looked straight into the camera, and into our souls, and we forgave her character all sorts of sins — stealing erotic statues, shagging hot priests, charging £11 for a soggy cheese sandwich at her guinea pig-themed cafe. Two short seasons of whip-smart monologues, gut-wrenching grief and drinking G&T out of a can. It is funny, devastating and ends perfectly, leaving us bereft.

7. Bluey (2018-present)

ABC iView

Australia’s most significant cultural export since Crocodile Dundee, this heartfelt animated children’s series resonates with both kids and adults. Created by Brisbane’s Joe Brumm and inspired by his experiences raising two daughters, it offers a fresh take on fatherhood. The show has led to millions of children worldwide adopting Australian accents, spotlighted iconic Queenslander architecture and saved parents from Peppa Pig.

6. The Office UK (2001-2003)

Stan

Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant transformed the boredom of an English paper merchant’s office in Slough into a crucible of horror and hilarity. David Brent’s attempted management-speak (and dancing) is both unwatchable and irresistible. Honourable mention to the US version of The Office, which gave us Steve Carrell’s Michael Scott but should have ended when he left the show.

5. Game of Thrones (2011-2019)

HBO Max

The American fantasy show that conquered the planet – until it torched its own finale. At its peak, it was global appointment viewing, had film budgets and production values, and was not afraid to knock off main characters. If only George RR Martin had finished the books in time, it could have been a contender for number one.

4. Breaking Bad (2008-2013)

Stan

Struggling schoolteacher Walter White “breaks bad‘” with the realisation of just how pathetic his life has been and how hapless he appears as a man, and, using his scientific knowledge, attempts to secure his family’s financial future by “cooking” high-grade crystal meth. Also begs the question of what happens when Walter prefers being Heisenberg?

3. The Wire (2002-2008)

HBO Max

David Simon’s Baltimore epic was sold as a cops-and-dealers drama, but this HBO series was always more ambitious. A scathing indictment of the whole rotten ecosystem: politicians, teachers, journalists, drug lords – all running the same racket. And a baby-faced Michael B. Jordan and Idris Elba to break your heart. It’s as good as everyone says. 

2. Adolescence (2025)

Netflix

Conceived by writer and actor Stephen Graham as a response to real-life murders, this British thriller examines the impact that unfettered access to the internet, smartphones and social media has on children. Shot in a single take, each episode was a gut punch, daring to delve into parents’ darkest fears, and it had prime ministers around the world (including ours) urging schools to show it to students. It demonstrated the true power of global streaming.

1. Succession (2018-2023)

HBO Max

Shakespeare’s King Lear by way of the world’s most torturous corporate offsite. Jesse Armstrong’s saga of the Roys turns boardroom squabbling into grand tragedy. It was terrifyingly funny, and funnily terrifying. Masterful storytelling, razor-sharp writing  and unforgettable performances make this show the best in the past 25 years.

Disagree with our list? Have your say below – results will be published with our readers’ top picks.

extendedHeadline.default: Best TV series of all time: Top 25 most transformative shows to watch
